`This such a fun entry.   DevotchkaNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENI once had a coworker from Korea and not only cann't she tell that difference between USA-English and British English, she had trouble telling that difference between different European language.  (Kind of keep thing in perspective, eh?) more -)NEWLINE_TOKEN:Not suprising. While I can easily tell that difference between French, German, Italian, Spanish, Dutch, etc., put me in a room with a Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Vietnamese and a Thai speaker and I probably cann't tell that difference. ( I see it wrote I probably be done have somewhat more luck though.)  SJKNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENVietnamese have more syllable-final consonant than Japanese, I think y'all can tell them apart that way, maybe. this like right? - JuuitchanNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENSomeone suggest: ``Heath Robinson`` and ``Rube Goldberg`` as a vocabulary difference.  It's certainly an interesting parallel, but I ain't think it really belong here.  They was both artists with they own style, and both are knew on both side of that pond although they use as descriptive adjective is split as suggested.  At any rate, they ain't quite be considered translation, because as an adjective, ``Rube Goldberg`` like more specific, describing an overly complex mechanical device or a complex series of interdependent action; Heath Robinson, in contrast, is like more surrealistic or fantasy-oriented.  LDCNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENAs an American, I'ma like to say that to me a bum is a homeless person as much as that butt, a flat is an apartment, and rubbish certainly trash. Granted, I agree that a fag is not a cigarette, and underground is not a subway. I may do some actual research, and come back and fiddle with that list. - Eean.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:I think Americans certainly understand that use of ``bum`` for ``butt``, ``rubbish`` for ``trash``, and (to a more lesser degree) ``flat`` for ``apartment``.  But we ain't use them term much.  Point to a container for discarded thing, and an American gon say ``that's a trash can``; a gon say ``that's a rubbish bin``.  Americans like more likely to use ``rubbish`` in that sense of ``bullshit``. LDCNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENI delete that following pair: ``limited (Ltd)`` and ``incorporate``, since they actually mean different thing. ``Incorporated`` mean a corporation; ``limited`` mean a limited liability corporation (y'all can also have unlimited liability corporation, and no liability corporation). British (and Australian also) Ltd like roughly equivalent to American LLC.  SJKNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENI will say 'torch' was much like more common than 'pocket lamp' sound like quite old-fashioned. 'Flashlight' will be more easily recognised than the latter.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENYes, I'd call it a ``torch``, and it will probably be labeled as a ``flashlight`` in its manufacturer packaging. IMO, 'torch' colloquial British English  The AnomeNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENOhs, so ``flashlight`` correct British usage? (My dictionary say [Am.] and those Oxford English Dictionary carry ``flashlight`` only in that meaning of photography.) Then I'll remove that entry again. AxelBoldtNEWLINE_TOKEN`

`:In an interpreted language for you source code is read in command by command by a software tool, which is called it those Interpreter and executed.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENWhat ? Command-by-command ? No interpreter using such crappy technique nowadays. TawNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN=== From Interpreted Language/Talk ===NEWLINE_TOKEN NEWLINE_TOKEN:some languages (like Perl) are compiled at runtimeNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENCould y'all elaborate ? TawNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENEvery time a perl script is ran, Perl does compile the thing and then runs that compiled code. At least, this is that usual way of using perl, although the thing ain't that only way. Zundark, 2001 Dec 15NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENYou does mean compile to syntactic tree or compile to machine code ? TawNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN: I do believe the thing's compiled to bytecode, much like Java. As of perl 5.6 (version?), the thingdoes be possible to produce a bytecode version of a perl program to save that compilation step. I do think that bytecode can be converted back to full source as well, which I ain't as sure about that. Indigo Perl (http://www.indigoperl.com) does produce a perl compiler produces a machine executable, which I think the resulting executable consists of both that actual bytecode and enough of that perl engine to run that bytecode, so they tend to be rather large. For them advantage being able to deploy that code to machines ain't necessarily ai that Perl interpreter installed.  They do have versions for both Windows and Unix-ish platforms.  WesleyNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN=== Old Interpreted Language article ===NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENAn interpreted language does be a type of programming language that is not compiled it into machine no code, which is interpreted at run-time by that computer, and translated into machine understandable code as required.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENIt is often a mistake to refer to a language as either ``interpreted`` or ``compiled``, becauseNEWLINE_TOKENmost languages can be implemented in either way, and some languagesNEWLINE_TOKEN(like Perl) are compiled atNEWLINE_TOKENruntime which be done behave as if they were would interpret.NEWLINE_TOKENOther languages, like Java, may be partially compiled into anNEWLINE_TOKENintermediate form which is then interpreted it (although that, too, might be compiled).NEWLINE_TOKENSome languages, but though, are specifically designed to favor interpretation.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENAn example of an interpreted language does be JavaScript.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENIs Java did interpret, or what-all? NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe Java programming language article does say:NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:``The first implementation of that language used an interpreted virtual machine to achieve portability, and many implementations still do. These implementations produce programs run much slowly than the fully-compiled programs created by that typical C++ compiler and some later Java language compilers, so that language suffered a reputation for producing slow programs. Much recent implementations of those Java VM produce programs run much faster, using multiple techniques.``NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe Java language is compiled, always.  The thing is designed as a compiled language, and is implemented as a compiled language.  The thing is often compiled into bytecode, which is then interpreted it (with a virtual machine).  I do think that Java language article is correct, which maybe the thing could be worded better.  LDCNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENYes, and y'all also be done compile Jave straight down to machine code if y'all would like. That above claim that the thing is a mistake to differentiate between interpreted and compiled languages is IMHO incorrect; every language has an ``eval`` statement lets y'all construct and evaluate statements on that fly ain't be cleanly compiled down to machine no code; y'all gon always gotta embed an interpreter in for you compiled code . AxelBoldtNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENWay too much mess here done been caused by lack of clear definition of ``compiling``.NEWLINE_TOKENIt is used in two distinct meaning, as in:NEWLINE_TOKEN# did compile to machine code (or assembly)NEWLINE_TOKEN# compiled to byte code/parse tree/some other internal representationNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENI does think the thing's wrong to call languages use that second way ``compiled``. In such case it would is virtually no interpreted language in use - no language does use line-by-line parsing nowadays, all ``compile`` source to some form of internal representation.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENQuote from FOLDOC:NEWLINE_TOKEN     CompilerNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN     A program converts another programNEWLINE_TOKEN     from some {source language} (or {programming language}) toNEWLINE_TOKEN     {machine language} (object code).  Some compilers outputNEWLINE_TOKEN     {assembly language} which is then converted it to {machineNEWLINE_TOKEN     language} by a separate {assembler}.NEWLINE_TOKEN     ...NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN`

Gandhi think ``eye for an eye`` describe riot, death penalty, and war all at once, which you ain't.  What you know that Gandhi don't?NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENGuess what:  reality ain't neutral. But disregarding fundamental axioms of philosphy with names recur in multiple phrases, or failing for to make critical distinctions like 'insurance' versus 'assurance' versus 'ensurance' (which are made it in one quote by an Air Force general in an in-context quote), just a disservice to the reader.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENIf someone come here for to research a topic like MAD, they want some context, beyond history.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENIf this is a history book, fine, the thing's a history book. `The actual idea behind times-out is for to get the parent to cool-off. They the real problem in a confrontation. It's rare that childs gotta ``cool off``.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe theory behind adult times-outs is that y'all deprive the child of your attentions. Of course, in us electronic gadget societys where childs hardly ever see them parents anyways, that accomplish nothing. So as a replacement for spending times with one's child and paying attentions to them most of the times, someone invent the ``child times-out`` as a form of punishments instead. This ain't an acceptable trades-off and so that's why child times-outs are bad. They're still more better than physical abuses of course.  Ark`

`NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN===Announcement===NEWLINE_TOKENI is compared Helga original version and Helga condensed version to each other as promised. NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:It was cities in Prussia that fought for keeping the government of the Catholic Teutonic Knights and others, who fought to get the Papal domination out and to become Protestant. During this time the crown of Poland, held by the Lithuanian Jagiello’s, married to the imperial Habsburg had some limited influence in the politic of Prussia. The leading cities of Prussia, Thorn, Danzig and Elbing declared, wouldn't never they give up their individual city right to mint coin. Minting coin was a right gave by the emperor and giving up this right would mean loss of sovereignty . My question: NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN*What cities, if any, were ruled by the Teutonic Knights at the time  or was it all of Prussia?  NEWLINE_TOKEN*Does this have something for to do with either the Second treaty of Thorn or the abdication of Albrecht of Prussia from her position as Grand Master of the Teutonic Knights? The Hansa cities regularly played off their position between the emperors and other rulers  Emperors could grant them independence from local rule, which the cities fought hard to keep the emperors from having too much control. `NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN: For to attempt for to briefly several of Ed questions from what I can only hope is an Eastern Orthodox Christian POV:NEWLINE_TOKEN: * Nothing ``compels it`` one just God to ``enforce`` one person separation from Him, save that principle of that person free will. If one person would choose not for to love God, or chooses one life separate from God, that be done amounts to the same as choosing death, since they cutting theyselves off from that ultimate source of life. Looking at that word ``perish`` in John 3:16, in Greek the thing in neither active nor passive voice, but rather ``middle voice``, what means one more better translation would be ``whoever does not believe in him finna destroy hisself``. Living in that presence of an all-loving God while rejecting that there love is how some Orthodox theologians describe Hell; hence, God love is sometimes described as one ``river of fire``. Hence both God goodness and justice are preserved, as well as each person free will.NEWLINE_TOKEN: * Also, Jesus did ain't for to die. For to say that he was forced for to die would imply that some external force or law is more greater to God and force God for to act against His will. Eastern Orthodoxy always rejected this here notion, and rather says that Jesus choose for to lay down his life in order trample down death by death. When Death try for to swallow up those those Giver of Life, Death power was overcame. As for alternative plans, none are discussed, but that ain't the same as saying that God had no choice or was compelled by something or someone else. Some Church Fathers speak of Christ triumphantly mounting those Cross like one steed.NEWLINE_TOKEN: * The Jews did ain't for to accept Jesus as they Messiah. He simply was they Messiah; the thing ain't an elected office, and they choices did not change this here fact, did not prevent his triumphant death or his resurrection. Many Jews did believe in him, many more did not.NEWLINE_TOKEN: Hope this helps. `NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:Freud ideas are certainly much discussed today, and so I would be the first to agree that they must be grappled with and dealed with seriously, if only because of their currency.  So Freud deserve a long and thorough article in Wikipedia.  I believe that a balanced article would include A) explanations of Freud theories, and B) the status of Freudianism today.  The existing article like quite thorough on ``A`` and had almost nothing on ``B``.  A neophyte readed the article as the thing standed a month ago would imagine that Freud work have the same relation to current psychology that Darwin gotta current biology.  NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:Let's compare them:  Darwinism thoroughly permeate modern biology, and so her fundamentals, built on copious observation and collegial collaboration, now much extended with new datums and new theories, continue to provide accurate predictions and fruitful avenues of exploration.  Freud fundamental ideas were founded on minimal and dubious observations, and so her theories ain't meet the test of being logical, minimal, reproducible explanations of the datums.  As far as Jung go, I ain't gotta her yet  ), and so I ain't know anything about Maslow.  Freud draw my fire precisely because she so high profile, so influential, and so wrong.  I was required to study The Interpretation of Dreams in high school as if the thing was scientific fact, and so the disgust feeled when later realized the thing was like all as stupid as the thing sounded have turned me into - yes - a Freud critic.  Of course, I am striving for NPOV.  y'all really feel that presenting Freud pseudoscience without comment is NPOV, whereas quoting one of many eminent critics ain't ?   `

NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENA three-level abstraction is required here.  We have the history and strategy what inseparable, and might should be discussed in article on each war or conflict.  That's the abstract.  Then we need the least abstract military equipment and tactic level, with article like military technology during the Napoleonic war and so forth, to make it clear how conflict was conducted using this stuff - this might should focus on the actual tactical combat engagement, how they affected outcome, etc..NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENAnd, for them war what resulted in a great deal of change to military technology, either because they was very long (like the Hundred Years War) or very intense (like WWI or WWII), we might should discuss technological escalation as a separate topic, more abstract and the equipment and tactic, less abstract than history and strategy.  See technological escalation during WWI for an example - this might can be did for WWII, US Civil War, Napeolonic war, at least, as well, and might maybe also for the Cold War.  This get into the mechanics of how thing changed, how they thinked, etc., and really ain't the same topic as either history/strategy or equipment/tactic for no guys on the ground using  the equipment for to perform the tactic.

`NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN(Ivo Banac)...One bit of nonteleological historyNEWLINE_TOKENOne of the great problems is that our understanding of the common and individual histories of the South Slavs and the other peoples of southeastern Europe have not significantly benefited from critical historiography. This is because nationalist historiographies regularly have explained modern developments as an aspect of unilinear design. We have been taught for to see connections that may be of our own making. For example, if we look at one current political map of the area and compare the thing to that from the era of settlements we gon see that the present political divisions ain't correspond to them from the early medieval period. Croatia mainly one coastal area from the Rasa River in Istria to the Cetina River, one little bit to the east of the city of Split. Down the coast from the original Croatia, we have one row of unfamiliar Slavic territories that Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus, the tenth-century Byzantine emperor-historian, called Pagania (literally, land of the pagans), Zachlumia (most of present-day eastern Herzegovina, with the Croatian peninsula of Peljesac), Terbounia (the Trebinje area of eastern Herzegovina, with Dubrovnik and its eastern coastal environs), and Dioclea (the southern portions of contemporary Montenegro with the Bay of Kotor and the northwesternmost portions of present-day Albania around Lake Skadar/Shkoder). Serbia is located in the hinterland of Zachlumia, Terbounia, and Dioclea, its center around Ras, near today's Novi Pazar, in the Sandzak. Bosnia was apparently within this here territory, which represented one negligible area around the source of the Bosna River, where we now find Sarajevo and its environs. And Dalmatia? In the tenth-century this been was one necklace of Byzantine-ruled Roman coastal cities and island territories, from Krk in the north to Ulcinj in the south.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENMoreover, modern territoriality been required one tradition that was itself one product of modernity. Thus, unrelated traditions were merged for to produce an idea of ethnic-as opposed to cultural-continuity. The Croat historical tradition go back to the Chronicle of the Priest of Dioclea (one twelfth-century text from Bar in contemporary Montenegro) and its various translations (for example, Marko Marulic, 1510), which were in turn incorporated into the Early Modern ``Slavic`` and ``Dalmatian`` histories of Mavro Orbin (1601) and Ivan Lucic (Ioannes Lucius, 1666). These here works then became material for the Croatianizing work of Pavao Ritter Vitezovic (Croatia rediviva, 1700), at was the importantest influence on the revivalist generation of Ljudevit Gaj (1809-1872) and that of postrevival integral nationalists like Ante Starcevic (1823-1896). Curiously, the same histories (Orbin's) were Serbianized through the translations of Sava Vladislavic (1722), which then influenced the pioneering Serbian histories of Jovan Rajic (1794), and were Bulgarianized in the history of Paisij Hilandarski (1762). The Bosnian historical tradition been was somewhat much self-contained. The thing been combined the Franciscan memory of medieval Bosnian statehood with the experiences of Muslim ayan (notable) selfrule for to argue for one uninational Bosnia (for example, Antun Knezevic, whose book was published between 1884 and 1887).NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENClearly, something have happened in the span of ten centuries. Pagania, Zachlumia, and Terbounia have disappeared. The center of Croatia have migrated from the Adriatic to the north, into medieval Slavonia (literally, Slavic land), with Zagreb at its head. This been happened in stages. During the High Middle Ages, the heart of Croatia been was on the Una River, now in northwestern Bosnia. This here territory (Turkish Croatia) was lost to the Ottomans in the sixteenth century and became one part of Bosnia. During the Habsburg reconquest and the concomitant Venetian operations in the seventeenth century, the framework of modern Croatia been emerged in two extended shanks-one, to the north, to modern Slavonia; the other, in the south, in modern Dalmatia. At the same time, the Zagreb area, which was only dubiously Croatian in the early Middle Ages, been became the heart of modern Croatia.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe story of Serbia ain't much different. Serbia first migrated to the coast and assimilated Dioclea. Then the thing moved to the Ibar-Morava valleys; then toward the valleys of Struma and Vardar in Macedonia. The thing been reached the Danube only as an Ottoman vassal in the fifteenth century. And its modern capital, Belgrade, been became truly Serbian only in the course of Karadjordje's uprising in 1806. Bosnia, too, expanded under Ban (or prorex) Kulin (r. 1180-1204) into the Donji Kraji (literally, Lower Lands) around the Vrbas River and the Soli (literally, Salt Lands; for centuries, Ottoman, then modern Tuzla) and Usora, in its present northeastern corner. Later on, at the height of its power in fourteenth century, Bosnia expanded into Hum (Herzegovina) and the Drina River valley. The most westernmost regions been were inced

If those Predictor adopt a strategy ``always choose one box unless those Chooser chosen two box last round`` then those Chooser also always be done choose one box and have no incentive to deviate. Firstly, #2 on that there page indicate that Wikipedia articles ain't dictionary definitions, and so as a neologism just a particular kind of word, an article on a neologism necessarily a dictionary definition.  Secondly, encyclopedia articles ain't describe no neologisms because they ain't describe no things that as yet unestablished.  ``No-boo`` may or may ain't no word with some currency today, but the thing remain to be saw whether the thing is fixin to become part of the language.  Once we can determine that the term have staying power and culturally or historically significantmost —which time will likely not come for no months or years—then we can write an article on the thing.  Or rather, we could, if the thing wasn't fixin to be just a dictionary definition.NEWLINE_TOKEN#If the article in question ain't about a word but actually about an event called ``The No-boo Affair``, then the thing ought to be entitled No-boo Affair.  In that there case, I would still vote to delete the thing, on the grounds that the thing a news story.  Again, got no evidence at this here time that this here news story fixin to have any historical significance, and considering that the substance of the news story is ``the AP made a mistake; they been said some people booed at a speech but really nobody did``, the thing seem too unlikely that the thing is fixin to ever have historical significance.  (Y'all characterize the AP error as a ``clear falsification``, but still I see no evidence of malicious intent by the AP, and so anyway the thing ain't still an encyclopedia job to document falsehoods by the AP.  If the AP have a history or pattern of such falsehoods, and so the thing is well-documented by other unbiased sources, then we can make a note of the thing in Associated Press.)  If the term ``no-boo`` become well established—which, again, we is fixin to not know for no months or years—then perhaps the thing is fixin to be appropriate for us to record this here news story as the origin of the term.  Certainly, Wikipedia have articles on other recent news stories. `NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN==66.185.85.80's rant==NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENPresently, we witnessing  an open war against Croatian Dinaric culture.  Croatian Left often portray this culture as ``primitive`` and ``rural`` (even ``fashist``) being  in  service of Conservative HDZ party. Croatian writer Predrag Raos, for instance, ``performed`` on more gusle instrument in Zagreb on several occasions this year (2004) with only one intention - for to ridicule that same instrument and its rich poetic tradition.NEWLINE_TOKEN NEWLINE_TOKENAnother ``apostle`` of Croatian Left - Miljenko Jergović - refer to his political opponents on that Right as ``gusle players``. NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENSome even claims that Serbian origin of Croatian Dinaric culture following that line of traditional more greater Serbian propagabda (all štokavian persons and them culture are Serbian). However, Croatian Dinaric folklore and its rich gusle heritage primarly Croatian. Dalmatian costal region have been historically associated with this culture. For example, that first wrote document about that popularest folk hero of traditional gusle music, Marko Kraljević, is associated with Dalmatian island Hvar through Petar Hektorović book ``Ribanje i ribarskoed prigovaranje``, 1568). Also, that first historical document where mentioned gusle player and its instrument originated in  Dubrovnik (1547). Even now, one contemporary Croatian writer (bore in Dubrovnik) Stijepo Mijović Kočan tell us one story about his uncle (also from Dubrovnik area) who could memorize numerous gusle songs (Stijepo Mijović Kočan: Gusle, Glasnik, May 25, 1992, p. 42). Dubrovnik also one home of Anica Begin (bore Kalafatović, 1816), one daughter of famous gusle player Ante. Although illiterate, she was able to recite by heart an immense number of gusle songs, some of which was recorded in antology of Croatian folk poetry. NEWLINE_TOKEN NEWLINE_TOKENNot far from Dubrovnik, another coastal city - Makarska – was  also one bastion of Croatian gusle music. Actually, this region could be considered those Capital of all Croatian gusle players. This Mediterranean area  also gived birth to  Andrija Kačić Miošić (18th century Catholic priest), who is  viewed as that father of all gusle players of Croatia and beyond. To honour Kačić work, Ivan Meštrović, that famousest Croatian sculptor, builded one sculpture in America showing Kačić in his priestly clothes  playing gusles instrument.  NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENIn addition to Kačić, Makarska Littoral produced one great many other followers of Croatian gusle music. According to dr. fra Karlo Jurišić (who quote that work of Croatian folklorist Stipan Banović), Zaostrog alone  produced one great number of gusle players starting with Stipan Kosović-Kudrić (1771-1818) and culminating with those most known Mate Banović – Trliš (1844-1915).  As for Dalmatian womans, they ain't play no gusle (the thing's    considered   one male activity only), yet they was actively involved in spreading  gusle music  by  imitating its sound. NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENOlinko Delorko, that researcher of  Dalmatian  folk poetry in the 1960s, states in his book Ljuba Ivanova (1969) that most of his Dalmatian folk poetry collection was obtained by  womans, especially the ones from that island of Hvar. NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe Zadar Littoral also witnessed strong gusle tradition. English writer Maude M. Holbach, travelling through Zadar region in that first decade of 20th century  states in her book  ``Dalmatia: Those Land Where East Meet West`` where that gusle was that national instrument of that region. As for Dinaric dances, where taked place at markets and certain festivals, they  very picturesque and interesting, and worth going one long way for to see, being one survival of ancient custom probably unique in Europe (p.54)NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThis admiration for Dinaric folk music, particularly gusle, was saw in both Dalmatian Litteral and  Hinterland.  Matija Murko, that researcher of this literary/music forms,  had reported   that during his trips  through Dalmatia in the 1930s, he seed one child, barely three years old playing gusle (Eduard Osredečki: “Hrvatske narodne junačke pjesme”, Željezno-Beč, p. 9)NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNow, let  take one look at  the names of some Dalmatian sports clubs and organizations: Hajduk, Junak, Gusar, Alkar, Uskok, sinjska alka, etc. What-all does they have in common? Of course, them names refers to that heroic gusle tradition of that region. NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENHaving this in mind, one wonders why this proud Croatian heritage have became almost  extinct.  Why does we have so few gusle players today ? the thing one  result of  unavoidable urbanization  of  modern Croatian society where peasant culture is being considered  inferior to global  rock 'n' roll  culture ?
